forecast.no_outcome_scenario: May 2025 experiences elevated temperatures but falls short of the May 2020 record, possibly ranking 2nd or 3rd warmest May. forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: May 2025 exceeds the May 2020 record due to sustained regional heat waves across multiple continents, elevated ocean temperatures that remained high despite neutral ENSO conditions, and the continuation of the exceptional warmth seen in January and March 2025, pushing global mean temperatures above the +0.95°C threshold.
forecast.rationale: Several factors inform this forecast. The research assistant notes that 2025 has shown mixed temperature performance: January was the hottest on record, March ranked first or tied for first, but April was only second warmest, and Q1 2025 was the second-warmest first quarter. This pattern suggests 2025 is exceptionally warm but not consistently breaking every monthly record. Critically, the strong El Niño that persisted through May 2023-April 2024 has transitioned to neutral ENSO conditions. El Niño events typically boost global temperatures, so this transition likely reduces the probability of breaking records compared to the 2023-2024 period. The record to beat (May 2020 at +0.95°C) is substantial and was set during different climate forcing conditions. The fact that April 2025 was only second warmest is a notable contrary indicator - if 2025 were on a trajectory to systematically break all monthly records, we'd expect April to have ranked first. Good forecasting emphasizes the status quo, and the status quo based on recent patterns suggests May 2025 will likely rank in the top few warmest Mays but not necessarily claim the #1 spot. My forecast is not higher because the neutral ENSO conditions and April's second-place ranking suggest we're not in a record-shattering pattern for every month. It's not lower because climate change continues to push temperatures upward, 2025 has shown exceptional warmth in some months, and ocean heat content may remain elevated enough to support a record. I would revise upward if preliminary May data showed exceptional widespread heat anomalies, or downward if early reports indicated May was merely warm rather than exceptionally hot.
